title: na.numerical analysis - Solving a Certain Constrained Isoperimetric Approximation-Problem
body: This question is related to my question Differential Geometric Aspects of Rubber Bands , where I asked for a mathematical model of contracting rubber bands. In contrast to my former question, the situation is different here, because meanwhile I have devised a model, that seems appropriate and am now interested in solutions of the related mathematical questions (comments regarding physical aspects are however still welcome). A model for rubber bands prior to contraction the rubber band is modelled as a closed curve of length $2\pi$ closed. continuous, length-parameterized curve $$x_0(u): [0,2\pi)\ni u\mapsto\mathbb{R}^n$$ $$x_0(u+2\pi)=x_0(u)$$ $$\|\dot x_0(u)\|=1 $$ after the rubber band has been released and $\Delta t$ seconds have passed, it is assumed that it has contracted to $x_{\Delta t}(u)$ of length $2\pi-\Delta s$ with the following properties: $$x_{\Delta t}(u):[0,2\pi)\ni u\mapsto\mathbb{R}^n$$ $$x_{\Delta t}(u+2\pi)=x_{\Delta t}(u)$$ $$\|\dot x_{\Delta t}(u)\|=1-\frac{\Delta s}{2\pi}$$ Under the further assumption that the points of $x_0(u)$ are initially at rest and then are linearly accelerated on their way to position $x_{\Delta t}(u)$ , it is possible to calculate the final speed from the distance of the initial and the final position and thus to obtain a factor for energy consumption: $$s(t) = \frac{1}{2}at^2\iff a=\frac{2s(t)}{t^2}$$ $$v(t) = at$$ $$E_{kin}(t)\ \propto\ \frac{1}{2}v^2(t) = \frac{2s^2}{t}$$ The total energy, $\Delta E_{kin}$ , that is released during the time span $\Delta t$ , in which the rubber band contracts from its initial state, that is modelled by $x_0(u)$ , to its final state, modelled by $x_{\Delta t}(u)$ , is proportional to the integral over the squared distances between corresponding curve points: $$\Delta E_{kin}\ \propto\ \int_{0}^{2\pi}{\frac{\|x_0(u)-x_{\Delta t}(u)\|^2}{\Delta t}du}\ \propto\ \int_{0}^{2\pi}{\|x_0(u)-x_{\Delta t}(u)\|^2du}$$ Question: given $x_0(u)$ , $\Delta t$ and $\Delta s$ as defined above, how can the $x_{\Delta t}(u)$ , with the stated properties, be determined, that minimizes $\int_{0}^{2\pi}{\|x_0(u)-x_{\Delta t}(u)\|^2du}$ ?
